title: Why isn't all motion relative? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why isn't all motion relative? It is all relative. It’s possible to determine you’re not in an inertial frame of reference just by examining your frame of reference. But since you can’t distinguish between gravitation and acceleration via any test done inside the frame of reference, you still need to look outside to see if you’re in motion relative to anything. And even if you *are* in motion and it’s acceleration and not gravity you feel, you’re still in motion relative to *something*.

Because some forms of motion can be determined without needing to have a reference frame. This happens when any choice of reference frame cancels itself out when the details of the particular kind of motion is calculated. The standard example would be acceleration in Newtonian mechanics.
